user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of str_conn_error_:
```c
static const char *
str_conn_error_ (ssize_t mhd_err_code)
{
  switch (mhd_err_code)
  {
  case MHD_ERR_AGAIN_:
    return _ ("The operation would block, retry later");
  case MHD_ERR_CONNRESET_:
    return _ ("The connection was forcibly closed by remote peer");
  case MHD_ERR_NOTCONN_:
    return _ ("The socket is not connected");
  case MHD_ERR_NOMEM_:
    return _ ("Not enough system resources to serve the request");
  case MHD_ERR_BADF_:
    return _ ("Bad FD value");
  case MHD_ERR_INVAL_:
    return _ ("Argument value is invalid");
  case MHD_ERR_OPNOTSUPP_:
    return _ ("Argument value is not supported");
  case MHD_ERR_PIPE_:
    return _ ("The socket is no longer available for sending");
  case MHD_ERR_TLS_:
    return _ ("TLS encryption or decryption error");
  default:
    break;   /* Mute compiler warning */
  }
  if (0 <= mhd_err_code)
    return _ ("Not an error code");

  mhd_assert (0); /* Should never be reachable */
  return _ ("Wrong error code value");
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function str_conn_error_:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define MHD_ERR_AGAIN_ (-3073)
...
#define MHD_ERR_CONNRESET_ (-3074)
...
#define MHD_ERR_NOTCONN_ (-3075)
...
#define MHD_ERR_NOMEM_ (-3076)
...
#define MHD_ERR_BADF_ (-3077)
...
#define MHD_ERR_INVAL_ (-3078)
...
#define MHD_ERR_OPNOTSUPP_ (-3079)
...
#define MHD_ERR_PIPE_ (-3080)
...
#define MHD_ERR_TLS_ (-4097)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of any <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) in the provided function. The function only returns string literals wrapped with the _() macro; string literals reside in static storage and are not subject to out‑of‑bounds accesses by the string.h routines. The mhd_assert macro is a no-op ((void)0) and the other provided symbols are integer macros, none of which perform string handling. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
